title: 4 - Projections of extreme poverty under different scenarios
text:
Download data as csv




Note: Poverty rates are reported for the $3.00 per person per day poverty line (expressed in 2021 PPP dollars). Poverty is projected after 2024 based on per capita GDP growth projections in the June 2025 Global Economic Prospects complemented by the April 2025 Macro Poverty Outlook and the World Economic Outlook. title: 2 - Population living in poverty globally
text:
Since 1990, around 1.5 billion people have been lifted out of extreme poverty ($3.00). However, the population living on less than $8.30 per day has remained unchanged.









 Download data as csv




Note: Millions of poor are reported for the $3.00, $4.20, and $8.30 per person per day poverty lines (expressed in 2021 PPP dollars). Poverty is projected after 2024 based on per capita GDP growth projections in the June 2025 Global Economic Prospects complemented by the April 2025 Macro Poverty Outlook and the World Economic Outlook. The black horizontal line is drawn at 256 million which represents 3% of the global population projected for 2030, the World Bank Group’s target for extreme poverty.

title: 10 - Changes in the Global Prosperity Gap due to growth and inequality
text:
Download data as csv




Note: A decrease in the Prosperity Gap is an improvement in welfare. Growth is calculated as the log difference. Change in the Prosperity Gap is the sum of the (negative) growth in the mean income and the decline in total inequality. Positive growth in the mean decreases (improves) the Prosperity Gap; thus, in the figure, the contribution of the mean growth is shown as the negative of mean growth. That is, for all the periods in the graph, there was positive growth in the global mean, which is displayed as a negative contribution. Inequality is measured using the inequality measure related to the Prosperity Gap. Change in total inequality is the sum of changes in between country and within-country inequality. See Kraay et al (2023) for more details.
